Dear Trojan Family,
Your household may be eligible to receive Pandemic Electronic Benefit Transfer (P-EBT) benefits to buy food.
P-EBT is for children 5-18 years old who received SNAP food benefits for the month of March 2020 and children up to 21 years old who are certified for free or reduced-price meals at school in Texas during the 2019-20 school year. Children that attend a school that offers free meals to all students (Community Eligibility Provision or Provision 2) are also eligible.
The online application for P-EBT is now open. Please review the criteria to see if you need to apply to receive these benefits. You will need your child's ID# but if you do not know it check their report card for the # or login into the parent portal for the ID# or ask your student.
Click link below for application link and criteria.

CONGRATULATIONS TO MS. APRIL BRUENE! 2019-2020 MORENO JR. HIGH CAMPUS TEACHER OF THE YEAR!
A theme that defines me as a teacher is teaching for meaning which fosters personal engagement with academic content. While studying the American Revolution, I have each student assume an identity of an historical figure. This identity is used to speed date, reenact events, and product a project such as a tombstone. Student comments such as “Hey King George, what were you thinking when you closed our harbor? Did you think we were just going to lay down and take that?” tend to be bantered around my room throughout the unit. In anticipation of the upcoming interactive lesson, students frequently ask if s/he can participate since their character is already dead. My response is always “Yes, I believe in reincarnation! You are going to return as a brave minuteman of Lexington.” Besides being fun, these types of spontaneous interactions demonstrate student engagement in what could be perceived as boring content.
#BeInSpireD #LoveMyStudents

Stay safe, keep learning.

The Joe Barnhart Scholarship Program
February 25 at 4:25 PM ·

On Thursday, March 5th, during a 9:15 a.m. assembly, the Joe Barnhart Scholars Award will be granted to one full-time junior at A. C. Jones High School.
The purpose of the award is to encourage superior students to excel. The award is not necessarily based on the highest academic standing and takes into account the student’s potential for contributions to the world in the areas of civics, religion, other humanities, business or professions. The award amount is $10,000 and may be given for four years for a possible total of $40,000. A one-time award, the Maggie Price Scholarship Award, of $10,000 will be given in the first year of college to the three remaining finalists.
Each of the four finalists this year is representative of an all-around student. All are ranked in the top 10% out of a class of 235 and have a resume that details many varied activities.

Here is some important information regarding parking at Friday's game against El Campo.

Once the lot at Travis Middle School is full, you will have to park at the Calhoun High School parking lot which is located across I35. We are the HOME team so BISD rules and policies will apply.

Posters, banners are allowed and must be removed immediately after the game ends. Powder, confetti, glitter, silly string, streamers, etc…are prohibited.

Noisemakers
Artificial noisemakers such as air horns or whistles are prohibited.

Man-made noisemakers (jugs with beads, inflatable boom sticks, clackers, cowbells) are allowed.

Take the National Red Ribbon Campaign Pledge to help fight the war on drug abuse and be a part of the creation of a drug free America:

As parents and citizens, we will talk to our children and the children in our lives about the dangers of drug abuse.
*We will set clear rules for our children about not using drugs.
*We will set a good example for our children by not using illegal drugs or medicine without a prescription.
*We will monitor our children’s behavior and enforce appropriate consequences, so that our rules are respected.
*We will encourage family and friends to follow the same guidelines to keep children safe from substance abuse.
Visit RedRibbon.org to learn more about this awareness campaign and how to get involved.
#BeInSpireD #redribbonweek
